original_text: presents a pipeline architecture for model inference in a scientific study related to predicting probability distribution for next-month default status. The study utilizes Freddie Mac's single-family mortgage monthly performance data spanning from 2012 to 2022. The pipeline architecture is composed of three main stages: 1) Sequences (Chosen Time Window and Feature Set), 2) Logistic Regression (Class-Weighted Random Forest, Tuned & Balanced LSTM, and Transformer), and 3) Cold-Start Handling: Early Observations, Market Benchmarks & Origin Attributes.

original_text: is a set of four line graphs, each representing the performance of a model in predicting mortgage delinquency across different time windows and feature sets. The key scientific insight from the figure is that the performance of the model in predicting mortgage delinquency improves as the time window for data analysis increases, with the 10-year window showing the best performance. This finding relates to the research objectives by demonstrating the importance of considering a longer time window for data analysis in predicting mortgage delinquency, which could be useful for financial institutions and regulators in making informed decisions related to mortgage lending and risk management.

original_text: presents a comparison between the proposed LSTM-BEKK model and several benchmark multivariate volatility models. The comparison is conducted on high-dimensional portfolios constructed from the top 100, 175, and 250 equities by market capitalization in the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan. The data is visualized through two line graphs, one for Microsoft (MSFT) and the other for Apple (AAPL), highlighting their predominantly positive covariance.

original_text: illustrates the in-sample variance estimation of the Apple (AAPL) stock price using a LSTM-BEKK model and several benchmark multivariate volatility models. The visualization shows the variance of the AAPL stock price over time, with the LSTM-BEKK model outperforming the other models, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed model in accurately estimating the stock's variance. This finding supports the research objectives of evaluating the scalability and generalizability of the LSTM-BEKK model in high-dimensional portfolios, as well as its superior performance compared to existing models.
